commit_message:
Use bisect to search sorted rows

The Python OVS library returns lists in sorted order. When searching

subject: crypto - revert EC container update overrides to X-Backend-*
commit_message:
crypto - revert EC container update overrides to X-Backend-*

We previously changed all container update override headers to use an
X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override- namespace so that they
would be persisted, replacing the former
X-Backend-Container-Update-Override- names. The only existing usage
prior to encryption was for EC PUTs. We made sure that the object
server would still accept the X-Backend-Container-Update-Override-
headers in case a proxy had not been upgraded. In that case the object
server already has workarounds for those headers not being persisted.

However, the previous change did not cater for a proxy server being
upgraded before an object server. The proxy server would start to use
X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override- headers in EC PUT requests
which the older version object server would not recognise for the
purposes of constructing container update headers.

This patch reverts the proxy controller to use
X-Backend-Container-Update-Override- headers in EC PUT
requests. Encryption middleware (and any future usages of overrides)
continues to use X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override-
headers. Since that is a new feature that must be explicitly
configured into existing systems it is more reasonable to assume that
all servers will be upgraded before introducing the feature, and with
it the new header usage.

Change-Id: Ife9f5084a799b339f2d6b176ae7fad4497b19d67

subject: Aodh upgrade heat template and manifests to replace ceilometer alarms
commit_message:
Aodh upgrade heat template and manifests to replace ceilometer alarms

This step needs to be run after the major-upgrade-pacemaker-init.yaml
step. It is split in three parts:

1) The first part is a shell script that disables old ceilometer alarm
pacemaker resources and removes related constraints and packages.

2) Here we run a small puppet manifest that configures aodh under httpd
via wsgi. We explicitly disable httpd's restart because by restarting
httpd manually via systemctl we risk that pacemaker's monitoring action
might happen exactly at that point and hence it will notice httpd being
down and initiate a stop/start action which will make the puppet
manifest fail. Also note that aodh uses the same backend as ceilometer.
This ensures the existing ceilometer alarms work without any need for
migration in aodh.

3) The last step is another small puppet manifest that takes
care of creating the aodh notifier, evaluator and listener pacemaker
resources and their constraints. We also restart the httpd-clone
resource to make sure that httpd is restarted with the new aodh under
wsgi configuration. This is in a separate step because we need the
guarantee that a) all packages are installed on all nodes before
creating the pacemaker resources and b) all wsgi configuration is
completed on all nodes before we restart httpd.

The rationale for this approach is that we want this
step to be verifiable on its own. That is the reason we actually
restart httpd at the very end. We want to make sure we can
verify aodh is working correctly under httpd before doing
the next upgrade steps. Note that we also include the horizon
classes in both puppet manifests in order to avoid wiping out
the horizon vhost configuration from apache.

Closes-bug: #1581504

subject: ICMP type & code validation while adding Security Group rules
commit_message:
ICMP type & code validation while adding Security Group rules

While adding new 'Security Group Rule' viz. 'Custom ICMP rule' when
wrong ICMP 'type' or 'code' was given the errors it would show were
'Not a valid port number'; which is misleading. The errors should
rather be 'Not a valid ICMP type' or 'Not a valid ICMP code'.

Also for validating ICMP 'type' and 'code' there wasn't any dedicated
functionality in 'oslo.utils/netutils' so the code for validating 'TCP
ports' was used. TCP ports are in range 0 to 65535 while ICMP 'type'
and 'code' are in range 0 to 255, so using 'TCP port validation' code
is incorrect.

When -1 is used in 'ICMP code' or 'ICMP type' that means any number
0 to 255 is valid.

Here newer dedicated functionality of 'oslo.utils/netutils' is used
for validating ICMP 'type' and ICMP 'code'.

subject: Make queues lazy in subscriptions
commit_message:
Make queues lazy in subscriptions

Currently queues are lazy on operations with messages, but not with
subscriptions. It means the user is forced to pre-create a queue before
creating a subscription to the queue, which is not very convenient.

Also currently if a queue has a subscription, the subscription will
stay on even if the user will delete the queue. But even if so Zaqar
will still work normally. This is strange that subscriptions can exist
with deleted corresponding queues, but it's impossible to create a
subscription to yet unexising queue.

This patch makes queues lazy also on operations with subscriptions, so
the user will be able to subscribe to yet unexisting queue.

Also this patch modifies tests, to make sure Zaqar's subscriptions
work both with pre-created queues and non-existing queues.

subject: Stop passing TestResources to Managers
commit_message:
Stop passing TestResources to Managers

Dynamic credential providers generate TestResource objects, which
behave like Credentials but also include network resources.
We used to pass those directly into client managers, but that has
several issues: the interface of the client manager is confusing,
because it accepts two different type of objects in one parameter.
Having the client manager depending on the dynamic credential provider
is a problem because in turn that depends on the client manager,
which may lead to circular dependencies when trying to make those
stable interfaces for tempest.lib.
Finally TestResources seem to confused developers, since a number of tests
ignored the possibility of getting Credential fields from TestResources
directly, and went through the inner credentials atttribute.

I think the best approach for now is to pass auth.Credentials objects
only into the client manager. The client manager does not use the
network resources anyways.

We plan to refactor the link between credential provider and network
resources anyways, so it's better to have that outside of client
managers.

Change-Id: I71d4587bf0b640d05d0f78fb84364ce4d2d021f3
Partially-implements: bp client-manager-refactor

If an allowed_address_pair port associated with a FloatingIP

should inherit the service_ports host binding and device

subject: Add available flag to plugin loaders
commit_message:
Add available flag to plugin loaders

Currently when iterating through plugins all plugins are loaded and
returned to the user. This is confusing for things like the kerberos
plugin where the required dependencies may not be available.

Add an available property on plugin loaders. Plugins that do not wish to
be shown to users can set available to false.

The lack of tests on this patch is unfortunate however any testing
involes a lot of mocking at levels lower than keystoneauth interact with
(i've tried). We would need to mock the pkg_resources layer that
stevedore uses and are essentially testing that EnabledExtensionManager
is doing the right thing.

I encourage people to verify this manually.

Closes-Bug: #1589740
